speaker.details: Sebastian begleitet die IT-Industrie bereits seit mehr als zwei Jahrzehnten; als Redakteur, als Beobachter, als Zuhörer. Er verantwortet bei Software & Support Media den Bereich Content und leitet die Teams, die redaktionell für Magazine und Konferenzen auf der Plattform entwickler.de bzw. devm.io verantwortlich sind .

Michael Hofmann is a freelance architect, consultant and developer. He has been gaining project experience for more than 2 decades on the German and international scenes, mainly in the areas of software architecture, Enterprise Java and DevOps. Since 2015, he has been increasingly involved with topics related to microservices architectures. In addition to his project assignments, he is active as a speaker at various conferences or as an author of professional articles and books (current eBook: "Von Monolithen und Microservices: Funktionierende Microservices-Architekturen erstellen").

Julius Mischok ist Gründer und Geschäftsführer der Mischok GmbH und verantwortet die Bereiche Entwicklung und Systeme. Der Dienstleistungsbetrieb plant und realisiert maßgeschneiderte Digitalstrategien, die mittelständische Partner fit für die Zukunft machen. Mit mehr als 20 Jahren Erfahrung in der Softwareentwicklung legt Julius großen Wert auf hohe Softwarequalität und moderne Teamarbeit. Sein Wissen gibt er unter anderem als Dozent in der Mischok Academy weiter.

Thomas is working as trainer since 1998 and for container technologies since 2015. With a background in Java and Web development as well as operations and DevOps Thomas offers rich and diverse know-how. Thomas is available for remote and on-site trainings and workshops.

Christian Schneider is a renowned security architect, experienced white hat hacker, and dedicated trainer in the field of IT security. He uses his expertise to support companies with penetration tests and security architecture consulting. Christian also assists teams in implementing agile threat modeling processes to promote a proactive approach to security. As an experienced trainer, Christian provides his participants with practical knowledge and proven methods to further expand their IT security expertise.

Russ Miles hat es sich zur Aufgabe gemacht, als Autor, Zuhörer, Redner und Entwickler Menschen dabei zu helfen, in einem der härtesten und potenziell einflussreichsten Arbeitsumgebungen erfolgreich zu sein: Software System Engineering. Als Experte für Chaos Engineering, Resilience Engineering, Sicherheit und Softwarearchitektur hilft Russ den Menschen durch seine Bücher, Mentorenschaft, Open-Source-Beiträge, Vorträge, Kurse und seine tägliche Arbeit, das Komplizierte und Komplexe zum Erfolg zu führen.
Russ möchte Menschen, die für die Entwicklung und den Betrieb einiger der kritischsten softwarebasierten Systeme von heute verantwortlich sind, dabei helfen, nicht nur zu überleben, sondern (mit Stil) zu gedeihen. Russ aims to help people that are responsible for building and running some of today's most critical software-based systems to not just survive but thrive (with style).
Russ ist per E-Mail unter russ@russmiles.com, auf [Linkedin](https://www.linkedin.com/in/russmiles/) und auf [Twitter](https://twitter.com/russmiles) zu erreichen.

Jay Shah is a Cyber Security Professional. He has about 8+ years of experience and has worked in various backgrounds including Telecommunication sector, Financial Industry, Consulting firms, and in Educational organizations. His expertise and focus is on Generative AI, Data Security, Cloud Adoption, Cyber Security, Chatbot Implementation, Privacy & Trust and Risk Management. Jay is a Technology Educational Consultant, Global Speaker and a Community Builder. He is Academic Leader for Canada DevOps Community of Practice and is Young Professional Member for IEEE. He has several Cyber Security and Cloud certifications in Oracle and Azure. He is certified DevSecOps Leader and Scrum Master. He has been a global speaker at several conferences and has several IEEE International Journal Paper Publications.

When not working on smartmessages.net, supporting 1CRM at syniah.com, writing & pentesting for Radically Open Security, or acting as a DPO, I'm the maintainer of PHPMailer, the second-most forked PHP project on GitHub, and probably the world's most popular email sending code. I'm a contributor to many other open-source projects, I write songs about open-source, and I wrote the HTML5 email address spec. I'm an accomplished PHP coder, Linux sysadmin, technical writer, and MySQL DBA. I'm a strong advocate of digital rights and privacy – I love GDPR! I've been speaking at technical conferences around the world since 2006. I live in the French alps with my wife, kids, cat, guitars, bikes, and far too many skis.

Erkan Yanar ist ein anerkannter Kubernetes-Experte mit umfangreicher Trainingserfahrung und laufender Projekttätigkeit. Seine Container-Expertise begann mit OpenVZ und Solaris Zones, erweiterte sich über LXC/LXD, systemd-nspawn und Docker und umfasst heute das gesamte OCI-Ökosystem. Zuvor war er als Open-Source-DBA tätig und baute einige der ersten großskaligen OpenStack-Installationen in Deutschland mit auf – zu einer Zeit, in der er sich praktisch als Linux-Administrator vervielfältigte. Heute unterstützt er Unternehmen bei der Einführung, dem Betrieb und der Absicherung von Kubernetes. Kein Wunder, dass er sich selbst gern als das „Ops“ in DevOps bezeichnet.

Christian Wenz ist Autor, Trainer und Berater mit Fokus auf Webtechnologien und Security. Christian hat über 100 Bücher für verschiedene Verlage geschrieben. Er arbeitet sowohl mit Open-Source- als auch mit Closed-Source-Webtechnologien, wodurch er sowohl mit einem Microsoft MVP für ASP⁄ASP.NET ausgezeichnet wurde als auch der Hauptautor der Zend PHP-Zertifizierung ist. Er ist auch in den Credits von Mozilla aufgeführt (about:credits) und trägt zu mehreren anderen Open-Source-Projekten bei. Neben dem Schreiben und der Arbeit an Webprojekten hält Christian auch häufig Vorträge auf (inter)nationalen Konferenzen, die sich mit Webtechnologien befassen.

Viktor Farcic is a lead rapscallion at [Upbound](https://upbound.io), a member of the CNCF Ambassadors, Google Developer Experts, CDF Ambassadors, and GitHub Stars groups, and a published author. He is a host of the YouTube channel [DevOps Toolkit](https://youtube.com/@devopstoolkit) and a co-host of [DevOps Paradox](https://youtube.com/@devopsparadox).

Constanze Roedig is key researcher at SBA Research, founder of the Kubernetes Storm Center initiative and Principal Investigator for European Open Science Cloud “Open Science Labs for High Performance Computing”. Her research interests span from complex systems dynamics — particularly the interplay between cyber systems and human behavior – to supply chain security and cloud runtime security using technologies like eBPF, WebAssembly, and AI. https://www.sba-research.org/team/constanze-roedig/

Neil is a seasoned technologist, dynamic speaker, and moderator with an unwavering passion for developer experience, engineering innovation, automation, and AI. With a proven track record in driving digital transformation and accelerating DevOps and platform engineering initiatives across industries such as finance and healthcare, Neil stands at the forefront of shaping the future of software engineering. A visionary thinker, Neil transforms intricate technical challenges into clear, actionable insights. He crafts scalable solutions that simplify complexity and significantly enhance the developer experience. As a senior Product evangelist at Fujitsu UVANCE—a global consulting and transformation firm, Neil leads projects that seamlessly integrate cutting-edge technology, automation, and developer support, setting new benchmarks for sustainable engineering. Neil has delivered acclaimed talks including DevOps' Dirty Little Secret and Inertia vs Innovation.

Niko Köbler ist Freelancer und seit über 10 Jahren als KEYCLOAK- und IAM-Experte für Kunden aus unterschiedlichen Branchen europaweit tätig. Auf YouTube betreibt er seit Anfang 2021 einen erfolgreichen KEYCLOAK-Channel und unterstützt die Community in verschiedenen Foren. Außerdem ist er ein bekannter und gefragter Sprecher auf IT-Konferenzen, Co-Lead der JUG Darmstadt und schreibt als Autor Artikel für verschiedene Fachzeitschriften.

Martina Kraus ist seit ihren frühen Jahren in der Welt der Webentwicklung aktiv und hat sich im Laufe der Zeit zu einer Expertin auf dem Gebiet der Websicherheit entwickelt. Als Application Security Engineer konzentriert sie sich darauf, Sicherheitsbest Practices in alle Phasen der Softwareentwicklung zu integrieren. In ihrer Rolle als Google Developer Expert (GDE) liebt sie es auch, Wissen über Websicherheit auf nationalen und internationalen Konferenzen zu verbreiten, organisiert regelmäßig ngGirls-Veranstaltungen (kostenlose Angular-Workshops für Frauen) und die deutsche Angular-Konferenz NG-DE.

Aurélien SVEVI is a seasoned application security expert with seven years of experience helping enterprises bridge the gap between security and development. Based in France, he has a proven track record of making application security not just effective, but truly engaging for teams. With deep technical expertise and a knack for simplifying complex security challenges, Aurélien ensures that security becomes an enabler—not a blocker—for development teams. His passion for DevSecOps, team integration, and security education empowers organisations to build resilient, secure applications with confidence.

Paul Senkel, a Solutions Engineer at Contrast Security, took an unconventional path in IT - starting his career in France, spending 14 years developing enterprise portals, and later consulting in Germany with a focus on mobile apps and banking. Frustrated by poor security and quality in software, he stepped away from IT to support his wife in coaching their three kids - who all launched their own businesses at 18. Paul returned to IT in 2022 when he discovered how Contrast Security’s modern, sensor-based approach solves the very issues that once drove him away. A passionate advocate for freedom, workplace happiness, and the right to use great tools, Paul brings deep insights into learning, motivation, and security culture. In his free time, Paul learns Hungarian and enjoys running with the family’s Hungarian Vizsla through town… without a leash, of course. It’s all about freedom.
I am Project Manager for a reputed organisation in Ireland. Having led software development teams in India, UK, UAE and Ireland, I have expertise in Cyber security and DevOps.

Dr Renato Samperio holds a B.Sc. in Computer Science from Tecnológico de Monterrey (2002) and earned his Ph.D. in Robotics and Intelligent Machines from the University of Essex (2008). Early in his career, he led research and engineering projects in unmanned mobile and space robotics across premier German and U.K. institutes and drove innovation within Switzerland’s robotics startup ecosystem. Since 2020, he has applied his expertise in secure, compliant infrastructure and automation as an IT professional at Zurich Insurance Group, specialising in DevOps and hight performance computing.

With six years of experience in data analytics and management, Nisha specializes in transforming complex data into actionable insights. As a Senior Data Analyst at Walmart, she navigates the intersection of tech and retail, leveraging data analytics, AI, and machine learning to drive business impact. Nisha possesses expertise in data analytics, business intelligence, stakeholder management, and AI development, with strong technical proficiency in SQL, Python, Tableau, and cloud platforms (AWS, Azure, GCP, Oracle). Passionate about AI, Generative AI and its applications, she has published research on "Building AI Chatbots Using Oracle Cloud" and has been a speaker at IEEE conferences, SkillupDays by PeopleCert, and the DevOps Summit, discussing AI and project management. Holding multiple cloud and AI certifications, including Oracle, Azure, AWS, GCP and IBM AI Certification, Nisha is also a Certified Scrum Master.

Kris Buytaert is a long time Devops and Open Source Expert and Engineering Leader. He's one of instigators of the devops movement, working for Inuits.eu / o11y.eu He started more than one conference series and lost count on how many times he spoke at other events. He spends most of his time working on bridging the gap between developers and operations , while warning people not to make the mistakes he made. He builds infrastructures that can survive the 10th floor test, or a datacenter fire, while actively promoting the devops idea ! He hasn't blogged for a while but people still point out the title of his blog. Titled "Everything is a Freaking DNS Problem" ,it can be found at http://www.krisbuytaert.be/blog/

Roland Baum holds degrees in Business Administration (Dipl.-Kfm. FH) and Business Informatics (Dipl.-Wirt.-Inf. FH) and has dedicated his professional career to the field of IT security. In 2020, he founded umbrella.associates GmbH and has since focused intensively on securing technical identities — a critical area still neglected in many organizations, yet increasingly exploited by cybercriminals as an effective and often underestimated point of entry.

Ben Linders runs a one-person business in Agile, Lean, Quality, and Continuous Improvement. Author of Getting Value out of Agile Retrospectives, What Drives Quality, The Agile Self-assessment Game, Problem? What Problem?, and Continuous Improvement. Creator of many Agile Coaching Tools, for example, the Agile Self-assessment Game. Ben is a well-known speaker and author, much respected for sharing his experiences and helping others share theirs. His books and games have been translated into more than 12 languages and are used by professionals all around the world. As a trainer, facilitator, coach, and advisor, he helps organizations with effectively deploying software development and management practices. He focuses on continuous improvement, collaboration and communication, and professional development, to deliver business value to customers. Ben is an active member of many networks, and shares his experiences in a bilingual blog, as an editor for InfoQ.com, as a practitioner in communities, and on Twitter: @BenLinders.

Martin Gegenleitner has been with Thales since May 2020 and works as a Presales consultant in the DACH region with a focus on Austria. His current topics are hardware security modules, key and secrets management in the context of hybrid and (multi-)cloud environments. Mr. Gegenleitner began his career in 2016 at a Thales distributor and was responsible for presales, professional service and support for the Thales (formerly Gemalto) product portfolio. As a member of the CISO team of a large international Austrian corporation, he faced the challenges of a multi-layered, distributed IT security landscape. Martin Gegenleitner studied Secure Information Systems at the University of Applied Sciences Upper Austria on the Hagenberg campus, where he completed his Master's degree.

Julian Iavarone has been Senior Sales Engineer for the DACH region at Imperva since May 2018 and has developed a strong expertise in Advanced Bot Protection and API Security over the last 15+ years. Previously, he worked at Rohde & Schwarz Cybersecurity, NTT Com Security and the German Armed Forces, among others.

Boris Cipot is a senior sales engineer at Black Duck. He helps companies of all shapes and sizes to create secure software. He specializes in open source software security, robotics, and artificial intelligence. He has also worked in the cybersecurity field since 2003 in anti-malware software at F-Secure and Avira.

Stephane is a Senior Solutions Engineer for EMEA at Docker, Inc helping companies to build, share, ship and run containerized applications faster and securely throughout the development lifecycle.
He is a passionate IT specialist combining technical and sales skills keeping the focus of having his customers and partners highly satisfied.
Stephane is also a member of the Continuous Delivery Foundation ambassadors team.

Brian Vlootman is an experienced security leader with over 25 years in IT and cybersecurity, currently serving as CISO at Backbase. At Backbase, he focuses on implementing a defensible security architecture and driving cyber resilience for the digital banking platform. His career includes offensive and defensive roles across different tech and security domains, spanning industries like banking and healthcare. He is passionate about bridging the gap between business and technical teams to foster a collaborative approach continuously improving security. He takes a pragmatic approach to cybersecurity, emphasizing measurable outcomes and the real-world effectiveness of tools and processes rather than theoretical perfection.

Nir is a Senior Security Researcher at OX Security, leveraging a career in software engineering and specialized cyber research. He brings deep experience in offensive and defensive cyber operations, coupled with hands-on work building ML models for malware analysis and embedded security R&D. This unique perspective is applied to tackling complex DevSecOps challenges.

Marcel Claassen is a Solutions Engineer specializing in cloud and container cybersecurity. He is known for his focus on threat detection and has more than 20 years of experience in the IT and Security field. Currently holding a position at Sysdig, a company focused on cloud-native security and actively contributing to open source projects such as Falco and Stratoshark. In his spare time he also manages home automation projects within his home based K3S cluster.

Ivan Kovačević is the Founder & CEO of CyberArrange Security Solutions, a Croatian company focused on delivering tools for automating cyber security exercise and training development, cutting training costs, reducing preparation time and strengthening cyber-readiness for SMEs and enterprise teams.
He received his PhD from the University of Zagreb Faculty of Electrical Engineering and Computing. After working for a while in the industry, he worked at the University on several research and development projects related to cyber security exercises, security of critical infrastructures, and monitoring of the Croatian web. Based on his PhD research, he established the spin-off company CyberArrange Security Solutions j.d.o.o., which develops technologies for automating cybersecurity trainings and exercises.

track.name: AI-Powered Security Automation with Testi McTestface

session.name: Neu hinzugefügte Session: Testi und sein McTestface
session.details: Das ist ein Testi McTestface …

session.name: QUIC and HTTP/3: The Next Step in Web Security and Testi McTestface
session.details: In recent years, the ways that we can deliver HTTP has improved in occasional leaps, from 1.0, 1.1, a big step to 2.0, and now 3.0. One of the biggest obstacles has been TCP, which isn't a great fit for HTTP, but we are stuck with it – or are we? QUIC is a reimagining of TCP that runs over "the other protocol", UDP, and integrates TLS 1.3, giving us a step up in performance and security. Discover how it works, how you can configure your servers and applications, deploy and test it today.

session.workshopRequirements:
Target Group:
Developers, architects and security engineers who have high security requirements for their microservices in Kubernetes clusters. Experience with Kubernetes is helpful.
session.longAbstract:
The starting point is the TLS/mTLS termination in the ingress gateway. From then on, all further communication within the service mesh is secured using mTLS. Outgoing communication is also checked and controlled with the help of the egress gateway. In addition, it is shown which request-based authorization checks can be taken over by the service mesh.

The associated security best practices are listed and explained for each sub-aspect. Since faulty security settings can have fatal consequences, the options available for error analysis are shown for each security aspect.

Agenda:

I. Fundamentals

  • Introduction to Service Mesh and Istio Ambient
  • Benefits of Istio Ambient compared to Istio (classic)
  • Istio Ambient and Zero-Trust

II. Ingress Gateway with TLS and mTLS

  • Ingress Gateway with TLS and mTLS
  • Security Aspects of Ingress Gateway
  • Troubleshooting Ingress Gateway

III. Peer Authentication

  • Activate mTLS for entire mesh
  • Co-existence of different workloads (with and without mTLS)
  • Troubleshooting mTLS

IV. Request Authentication

  • End-User Authentication
  • Prepare JWT and JWKS
  • JWT claim based routing

V. Authorization

  • AuthorizationPolicy
  • Establish default deny-all rule
  • Explicit deny of a request
  • Test new policies with dry run
  • Security Best Practices

VI. Request Authorization

  • JWT claim based authorization
  • JWT claim based routing

VII. Egress Gateway

  • Controlled access to external services
  • Troubleshooting Egress Gateway

VIII. Istiod Certificate

  • Istio’s Certificate Management


The slides and the code examples together with the Kubernetes/Istio scripts we will use are available to the participants.
session.workshopAttendeeInformationsEn:
Dear workshop participant,the technical requirements for the workshop are as follows:

On-site participants:
  • Laptop with an internet connection is required
  • Should have headphones with mic to collaborate with remote participants if needed.
  • Please think of a suitable socket adapter for your notebooks
Remote participants:
  • The workshop will take place exclusively in Zoom for remote participants. Communication will take place via Zoom Chat.
  • Audio (and video) setup to be able to actively participate.


Please have a look here to prepare for the Service Mesh Workshop:

https://hofmann-itconsulting.de/assets/servicemeshworkshop/TeilnehmerVorbereitungWorkshop.html#ambient-minikube


We wish you a successful workshop and look forward to seeing you!

Best regards,
Conference Team
session.name: Service Mesh Security Workshop with Istio Ambient: Manage mTLS, AuthN and AuthZ
session.details: In this workshop, participants will be shown the possibilities that a service mesh tool like Istio Ambient offers in terms of security. Istio Ambient enables a new service mesh architecture that completely eliminates sidecars. After a brief introduction to the service mesh, more and more security features are presented and implemented in each step.

session.name: Internal Developer Platform Day 2 Operations Solved
session.details:
In most cases, if we work very, very, hard, we could enable developers to create something meaningful. Most of us do that by creating abstractions. Instead of forcing developers to spend years trying to understand the intricacies of Kubernetes, we create Helm charts that enable developers to modify a simple YAML values file and apply charts to the cluster. If we are advanced, we create CRDs and controllers that result in even better abstractions and start resembling services that developers can consume. We progress further from there by creating services not only for applications but also for databases, clusters, or anything else. We platform engineers, become service providers, and developers start consuming those services. Here's the problem though, all that tends to help only with day 1 operations. Developers can create or update something in a very easy way, but when it comes to operating and observing that something, they often end up being equally confused as they were before. Our services do not show the information they need, so they need to dig deeper into lower-level resources to find out what's going on. That negates some of the main reasons we started offering them services. That's horrible. We're building something that looks useful when someone starts using it, and it turns useless afterwards.

In this talk, we tackle a major challenge in Internal Developer Platforms built on top of Kubernetes: enabling developers to not only manage their applications and infrastructure but also to observe and troubleshoot them effectively. We will demonstrate how to propagate meaningful status information to top-level resources. That will solve real-world issues by making day 2 operations easier for developers without overwhelming them with low-level details. We'll learn how to create custom resource definitions (CRDs) and controllers that simplify the developer experience and propagate relevant information up the hierarchy tree.

session.name: Secure your APIs: JWT or mTLS or both?
session.details: Authorized access to an API should be checked on the basis of cryptographically secured identities. This is the only way to clearly and securely identify the caller, which in turn forms the basis for an authorization check within the API. This creates the basis for robust and secure API communication.JSON Web Token (JWT) or mutual TLS (mTLS) are available for this purpose. However, a combination of both technologies can also be useful. It is important to understand the basic purposes for which JWT (authentication) and mTLS (secure and verified communication) are suitable.After an explanation of the two technologies and their associated areas of application, the respective requirements as well as advantages and disadvantages are weighed up against each other. The synergy of JWT and mTLS will also be explained and analysed in detail. The aim of the session is to be able to better assess the sensible use of one of the two technologies or a mix of both for reaching a higher level of API security.

session.name: Real‑World DevOps Attacks: Breaches from Push to Prod
session.details:
Your automation pipeline safeguards the crown jewels of the business—source code, secrets, release keys—yet the very workflows meant to accelerate delivery can be leveraged against you. Attackers now aim for build scripts, workflow actions, container tags, and infrastructure templates to slip tainted components straight into production without tripping a single test.

This keynote is a guided walk‑through of several real‑world, headline‑making DevOps incidents. We’ll trace how each break‑in unfolded, pinpoint the pipeline stages that provided the attacker’s leverage, and unpack the common blind spots that let them succeed. Then we flip the perspective to show what teams did next and what mindsets keep pipelines safe without throttling velocity.

You’ll leave with a clear picture of the modern DevOps attack surface—from commit to deploy—and a concise set of questions to ask your own pipeline on Monday morning: Where are my crown jewels stored? How hard are they to reach? Whether you build, test, or operate, this talk arms you to ship fast and safe.

session.workshopRequirements:
- Having a github account and basic programming skills such as knowing python, java and linux. 

- Having basic cloud and cybersecurity knowledge is a plus point.
session.longAbstract:
The workshop will be broken down into primarily 3 Phases where we will cover the following areas and parameters around Generative AI Security & Critical Infrastructure Security

Phase 1 : Setting the ground with a real-world example of a Mortgage Lending & Health Care

company who has challenges with Gen AI and want to overcome risks

● Getting Started with Generative AI Security along with its Model Lifecycle

● Gen AI Risks and consequences in HealthCare and Mortgage Industry

● Use cases of prompt injection and hallucination activities using trained dataset


Phase 2 : After analyzing the use case and the Gen AI lifecycle, it's time to list out the Cyber

controls as per the industry category and see their capabilities considering AI Data Governance

● Secure AI Data Governance, Data Security, Privacy & Trust

● Approach to Securing Generative AI Capabilities

● Key Areas to Consider for Gen AI Related Security Controls


Phase 3 : Recommendations sample with cyber controls mapped against its frameworks

followed by Secure Gen AI Adoption Roadmap

● Recommended Gen AI security controls mapped with NIST AI-Risk Management

Framework

● Secure Gen AI - Value based Roadmap

● Responsible AI Principles & Frameworks


Towards the end you will get an overall understanding of establishing a strategic data governance framework for AI capabilities and will be developing a comprehensive AI strategy including industry wide best practices, Governance, Risk, Compliance, Risks Mitigation techniques, Government Policies and Standards.

Remote participants:

- Having a github account and basic programming skills such as knowing python, java and linux. 

- Having basic cloud and cybersecurity knowledge is a plus point.


We wish you a successful workshop and look forward to seeing you!


Best regards,
Conference Team
session.name: Confidence in AI Workshop- Securing Enterprise Generative AI Systems & Critical Infrastructure
session.details:
As Generative AI becomes deeply embedded in enterprise and societal systems, the question is no longer “Can we build it?” but it's rather “Can we trust it? And “How we can secure it”?

This strategizing and technical workshop explores how to establish confidence in AI—not just in terms of performance, but in security, privacy, transparency, and governance. We will unpack the unique security challenges and risks posed by GenAI, including adversarial prompts, model leaks, hallucination, and data misuse etc.

With real-world examples and emerging best practices, the session outlines how organizations can implement security controls such as red teaming, model monitoring, usage policies, access control etc. using various AI frameworks such as NIST AI-RMF and ISO 42001 and map it against various stages of Gen AI lifecycle from model development to model monitoring. We’ll incorporate AI development with regulatory frameworks, from GDPR to the EU AI & India AI Act etc. and highlight how organizations can embed governance into AI lifecycle through automation and policy enforcement.

Crucially, we’ll highlight the role of data governance & data security in building trustworthy AI from securing training data to ensuring regulatory compliance and ethical integrity. Attendees will leave with a strategic understanding of how to design GenAI systems with a forward-looking roadmap.

session.name: Magical Client-Side Logging – the Little Headers That Could
session.details: In a server side app, it's easy to find out what went wrong from logs. But what about the client side? How will you know when your CDN's DNS goes down, XSS is trying to steal data, or users in Belgium are unable to load your images? The W3C's Reporting API, Content-Security-Policy, Network Error Logging (NEL), and Reporting-Endpoints HTTP headers can let you know about all kinds of client-side issues that you'd otherwise never see. These browser features are new and evolving, making implementation a little tricky, so we will confront those issues and overcome them. Find out how to use them, and solve all the issues that only your customers have been seeing!

session.name: DevSecOps in the age of Generative AI
session.details: DevSecOps has transformed the software development landscape by emphasizing the importance of security throughout the Secure-SDLC lifecycle. By embracing DevSecOps principles and leveraging the power of AI and GenAI, organizations can deliver secure, reliable, and high-quality software that meets the demands of the ever-evolving digital world. The era of GenAI in DevSecOps is filled with both immense opportunities and significant risks. Organizations are now focusing on developing explainable AI models, implementing ethical AI governance, and conducting adversarial testing. The evolution of DevSecOps in the AI age reflects a shift towards more proactive, automated, and intelligent cyber security practices.

session.workshopRequirements:
This workshop is suited for all web developers and technical team leads. Experience with any web stack or framework is helpful, but not a hard requirement.

At one point during the workshop, we will look at a vulnerable web application. You only need a web browser for that. If possible, use a private laptop for that, since company VPNs and security software might interfere with our experiments there.
session.longAbstract:
This workshop will give you a holistic view of common web application security risks and mitigations. Our key focus is on awareness—you have to understand attacks in order to be able to anticipate them and create robust and secure applications. We will use the OWASP Top Ten and OWASP API Security Top Ten as an agenda, discussing each of the list items, but will focus on those that are most relevant for web applications today. The following topical blocks are planned:

The OWASP Top Ten

  • The OWASP and its role
  • The process behind the OWASP Top Ten

OWASP Top Ten 1-10

  • Looking at each item on the list
  • Deep-dives in important topics such as cross-site scripting, SQL injection, cross-site request forgery, server-side request forgery
  • Discussion of useful HTTP Headers to increase the security posture of a site
  • Exercise: Looking for cross-site scripting vulnerabilities in a web application

OWASP API Security Top Ten

  • Creation process of the API security top ten
  • Discussion of each item on the list
  • Deep-dives on important topics such as rate limiting, API authentication and authorization, CORS

More OWASP

  • Brief overview of other OWASP tools, software, and offering

session.name: Web Application Security Workshop with the OWASP Top Ten(s)
session.details:
Every few years, the Open Web Application Security Project (OWASP) publishes a list of the ten biggest security risks - regardless of the technology used. With some luck, the 2025 edition will be ready just in time for the conference!

Another top ten list looks at API security. We'll take the latest version of these two lists as an opportunity to look at the topic of web security: what attacks are there, what countermeasures are available, and which potential risks are not even on the top ten list, but are nevertheless extremely relevant and dangerous?

session.workshopRequirements:
Who Should Attend?

This workshop is tailored for DevOps engineers, security professionals, software developers, and technical leads seeking to enhance security in their GitHub CI/CD pipelines using open-source tools. While a basic understanding of GitHub Actions and CI/CD pipelines is recommended, it’s not mandatory.

Recommended Preparation:

To fully engage in the hands-on exercises, it’s beneficial to have a GitHub account (a commercial enterprise account is not required) in order to fork a repository used during the workshop.

For the optional section on understanding how DAST scanners can be applied, installing OWASP ZAP is helpful but not essential: If you wish to follow certain exercises directly live along, you can have the tool OWASP ZAP (OpenSource from OWASP) running locally. You can download it from https://www.zaproxy.org/download/ where the full Cross-Platform version is the easiest to use as it only requires unpacking. In case you want to use ZAP: Firefox is recommended as a browser due to its easy proxy integration with ZAP.
session.longAbstract:
Securing your DevOps pipeline is crucial to protecting your software from vulnerabilities and compliance risks. This workshop focuses on integrating security scanning into your GitHub workflows using relevant open-source tools. You’ll gain hands-on experience implementing essential security checks at different stages of the CI/CD pipeline, ensuring that security becomes an integral part of your development process.

Key Topics Covered:

* Security in CI/CD: Understanding the significance of security automation in modern DevOps pipelines.
* Relevant Open-Source Security Tools: Implementing security scans directly in GitHub pipelines (applicable to other pipelines as well).
* Static Application Security Testing (SAST): Detecting vulnerabilities early in the development lifecycle.
* Software Composition Analysis (SCA): Identifying insecure dependencies before deployment.
* Secret Leak Detection: Preventing credential leaks in repositories.
* Finding Management: Exploring IDE integration and code-pointers for enhanced security.
* Best Practices & Real-World Use Cases: Integrating security into your SDLC workflow effectively.
session.workshopAttendeeInformationsEn:
Dear workshop participant,the technical requirements for the workshop are as follows:

On-site participants:
  • Laptop with an internet connection is required
  • Should have headphones with mic to collaborate with remote participants if needed.
  • Please think of a suitable socket adapter for your notebooks
Remote participants:
  • The workshop will take place exclusively in Zoom for remote participants. Communication will take place via Zoom Chat.
  • Audio (and video) setup to be able to actively participate

Recommended Preparation:

To fully engage in the hands-on exercises, it’s beneficial to have a GitHub account (a commercial enterprise account is not required) in order to fork a repository used during the workshop.

For the optional section on understanding how DAST scanners can be applied, installing OWASP ZAP is helpful but not essential: If you wish to follow certain exercises directly live along, you can have the tool OWASP ZAP (OpenSource from OWASP) running locally. You can download it from https://www.zaproxy.org/download/ where the full Cross-Platform version is the easiest to use as it only requires unpacking. In case you want to use ZAP: Firefox is recommended as a browser due to its easy proxy integration with ZAP.

We wish you a successful workshop and look forward to seeing you!


Best regards,
Conference Team
session.name: Workshop: Secure Your GitHub Pipeline – Integrating Open Source Security Checks
session.details: Join this hands-on workshop, led by DevSecOps expert Christian Schneider, to learn how to integrate security into your CI/CD pipeline using powerful open-source tools. Gain practical knowledge on implementing essential security checks within your GitHub workflow and learn actionable insights into securing your software development lifecycle efficiently with open-source solutions. All the tool integrations demonstrated in the workshop can be applied to non-GitHub-based pipelines as well.

session.name: Bulletproof Web Applications: The 2025 OWASP Top Ten
session.details: Since 2003, the Open Web Application Security Project curates a list of the top ten security risks for web applications. The brand new 2025 edition of the OWASP Top Ten is on the horizon; time to take a look at it! What’s new, what has changed, and what is mandatory knowledge for any developer using a modern web stack? Attend this session to get an up-to-date refresh on how to create secure web applications and prevent the top ten issues from happening. Many code samples will demonstrate those risks, and countermeasures, to keep your applications secure.

session.name: SAML vs. OAuth vs. OpenID Connect – Which One Suits You Best?
session.details: We have 3 solutions - the protocols and specifications SAML, OAuth and OpenID Connect. But what problems do they actually solve? When do I use which protocol? Which one has which advantages or disadvantages? In this presentation, I will give an overview of the 3 best-known security protocols & specifications, which all are somehow related to authentication and authorization, but are nevertheless different from each other. I will discuss their features, compare them and give a few tips on when and why you should choose which solution.

session.name: OAuth2 and OIDC with Spring Authorization Server
session.details:
"Don't ever do this in the application! That's what identity services are for." Essential advice, as it can avoid a lot of redundancy, complexity and security issues. But what if the application itself is supposed to serve as an authorization server in terms of OAuth2 or OIDC? This requirement often arises in practice, especially in the context of identity federation or due to constraints from the business domain.
The Spring Security project "Spring Authorization Server" can be used as solid foundation for this, providing building blocks for many aspects. This talk will introduce the basic concepts of OAuth2 and OIDC, the structure of various bearer tokens, and the principles of the Spring Authorization Server. Using the framework will be demonstrated through code examples and demos.

session.workshopRequirements:
Target Group:

  • Web developers who want to build secure applications.

  • Software and security architects who want to implement security concepts effectively.

  • IT experts who want to develop their skills in web security.

  • Security enthusiasts who want to understand attack and defense techniques.
session.longAbstract:
Day 1: Security Fundamentals and Attack Vectors (9:00 AM - 4:30 PM)


1. IT Security Foundations


  • CIA triad and security principles

  • Encryption: Symmetric vs. asymmetric

  • Hashing methods and their applications

  • Hands-on: Encryption tools in practice

2. Browser Security mechanism


  • Same Origin Policy and Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS)

  • Cookie security: httpOnly, Secure, SameSite attributes

  • Session management and secure token strategies

  • Lab: Cross-Origin Resource Sharing

3.  HTTP Security Header


  • Configure security-relevant HTTP headers

  • Properly implement Content Security Policy (CSP)

  • HSTS, X-Frame-Options, X-Content-Type-Options

  • Lab: HTTP Security Header

4. Web Application Attacks Part 1


  • Intro into OWASP Top 10 2025
session.workshopAttendeeInformationsEn:
Dear workshop participant,the technical requirements for the workshop are as follows:

On-site participants:
  • Laptop with an internet connection is required
  • Should have headphones with mic to collaborate with remote participants if needed.
  • Please think of a suitable socket adapter for your notebooks
Remote participants:
  • The workshop will take place exclusively in Zoom for remote participants. Communication will take place via Zoom Chat.
  • Audio (and video) setup to be able to actively participate


We wish you a successful workshop and look forward to seeing you!

Best regards,
Conference Team
session.name: Web Security Bootcamp - Day 1
session.details:
This intensive two-day hands-on workshop teaches you to effectively secure modern web applications. Experience firsthand how attacks work and develop concrete defense strategies. From OWASP Top 10 to OAuth2 and Content Security Policy – master current security concepts through realistic scenarios and cutting-edge tools.

The workshop combines theoretical foundations with intensive hands-on exercises: identify vulnerabilities, implement security measures, and test your applications with professional security tools. After the camp, you'll be able to recognize vulnerabilities, develop secure APIs, and implement authentication with OAuth2.

Perfect for web developers, software architects, and IT security experts who want to future-proof their applications against evolving threats.

session.workshopRequirements:
Target Group:

  • Web developers who want to build secure applications.

  • Software and security architects who want to implement security concepts effectively.

  • IT experts who want to develop their skills in web security.

  • Security enthusiasts who want to understand attack and defense techniques.
session.longAbstract:
Day 2: Attacks on Web Application Defense Strategies and Modern Identity Management (9:00 AM - 4:30 PM)

1. ﻿Web Application Attacks Part 2

  • Cross-Site Scripting (XSS): Reflected, Stored, DOM-based

  • Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) and countermeasures

  • SQL injection and other injection attacks

  • DoS attacks and defense strategies

  • Lab Capture-the-Flag: Exploit vulnerabilities in test applications

2. Defense Strategies


  • Systematic protection against known attack vectors

  • Secure coding practices for modern frameworks

  • Input validation and output encoding

  • Hands-on: Secure a vulnerable application step by step

  • Manual vulnerability analysis: techniques and tools

  • Automated scanners: OWASP ZAP, Burp Suite, Nessus

  • Static Application Security Testing (SAST) vs. Dynamic Application Security Testing (DAST)


3. OAuth 2.0 and OpenID Connect: flows and best practices


  • JWT tokens: security and correct implementation

  • OAuth2.1/OIDC Flows

  • Identity provider integration in modern web applications

  • Common Threats and Best Practices

  • Backend for Frontend Pattern

Dear workshop participant,the technical requirements for the workshop are as follows:

On-site participants:

  • Please think of a suitable socket adapter for your notebooks
Remote participants:

  • Audio (and video) setup to be able to actively participate


We wish you a successful workshop and look forward to seeing you!

Best regards,
Conference Team
session.name: Web Security Bootcamp - Day 2
session.details:
This intensive two-day hands-on workshop teaches you to effectively secure modern web applications. Experience firsthand how attacks work and develop concrete defense strategies. From OWASP Top 10 to OAuth2 and Content Security Policy – master current security concepts through realistic scenarios and cutting-edge tools.

The workshop combines theoretical foundations with intensive hands-on exercises: identify vulnerabilities, implement security measures, and test your applications with professional security tools. After the camp, you'll be able to recognize vulnerabilities, develop secure APIs, and implement authentication with OAuth2.

Perfect for web developers, software architects, and IT security experts who want to future-proof their applications against evolving threats.

session.name: Inclusive Security
session.details: Inclusion ensures that diverse perspectives are considered, leading to products that cater to a broader audience and meet the needs of all users. By engaging with underrepresented groups during design and testing, and fostering a culture of collaboration, we can create more accessible and user-friendly applications. Simultaneously, security must be woven into every stage of the SDLC. Adopting a security-first mindset allows teams to identify potential vulnerabilities early, implement best practices for data protection, and ensure compliance with regulations. Regular security assessments and training are essential for maintaining a strong security posture throughout the product's lifecycle.

session.name: Continuous Compliance: Automation Pipelines in Regulated Financial Services
session.details: In this session, we’ll explore strategies for safely upgrading IaaS, SaaS, and other mission-critical back-end services within the stringent controls of financial regulation. We’ll examine how to balance the imperative to patch security vulnerabilities and resolve system inconsistencies against the risk that infrastructure changes may alter key calculation outputs; potentially triggering regulatory review and preserving audit trails and change controls. We introduce a “dual-run” strategy, where new and legacy environments operate in parallel to validate outputs, alongside comprehensive documentation and risk-assessment playbooks. Finally, we'll discuss how to reconcile mandatory security patches and configuration fixes with regulatory demands for stability in reported figures by using automation pipelines and AI-driven monitoring. At the end of the talk, you’ll have a concrete road map for implementing secure, compliant upgrades to ensure every infrastructure modification is fully justified, traceable, and compliant by combining impact analysis, stakeholder sign-off workflows, and evidence-driven reporting.

session.name: Resilience From Verifiable Trust: How the Bill of Behavior (BoB) Achieves Supply Chain Security and Removes Toil From the End-User
session.details: Regulations usually create effort and toil, but leave companies with questionable improvements on their actual security exposure: We introduce the “Bill of Behavior” (BoB): A vendor-supplied profile detailing known benign runtime behaviors for software, designed to be distributed directly within OCI artifacts. Generated using eBPF, a BoB codifies expected syscalls, file access patterns, network communications, and capabilities. This empowers powerful, signature-less anomaly detection, allowing end-users to infer malicious activity or tampering in third-party software without the current burden of authoring and maintaining complex, custom security rules. We will demonstrate the BoB specification's portability across diverse ecosystems, languages, and stacks. The main focus of our talk will be on emphasizing the vital role of user transparency and user experience in creating security implementations based on what we -the community- already have and know. Our goal is to strengthen Cyber Resilience by interpreting the EU CRA and EU NIS regulations into a meaningful technology implementation and thus empower EVERY cloud native practitioner with a shareable, composable, and actionable framework for runtime security, that requires minimal friction to adopt.... and that actually works.

session.workshopRequirements:
Who Should Attend?

This workshop is designed for:

- Developers & DevOps Teams – Learn how to build security into your applications without compromising performance.

- Security Engineers & SOC Analysts – Get hands-on experience in real-time threat detection and response within applications.

- IT & Security Decision-Makers – Understand how ADR enhances overall cybersecurity posture and protects against modern attack techniques.


Knowledge Requirements:

- Basic understanding of software development and web applications.

- Some experience with DevOps tools (CI/CD pipelines) and application deployment practices is beneficial but not mandatory.
session.longAbstract:
In today’s fast-paced digital world, cyber threats lurk in the shadows, waiting to exploit vulnerabilities in your applications. "Beyond Firewalls: DevOps-Ready Application Security with ADR" is a hands-on workshop designed to help developers, security teams, and IT professionals understand how Application Detection & Response (ADR) can detect and neutralize these threats before they cause damage.


What You’ll Learn:

This workshop will provide an in-depth exploration of ADR, covering:

- Understanding ADR & Its Role in Application Security – What makes ADR different from traditional security solutions like firewalls, and WAFs? How does it work in real-time threat detection?

- Common Attack Vectors & How ADR Stops Them – Learn how threats like zero-day exploits, supply chain attacks, and runtime injections can bypass conventional defenses and how ADR can detect and respond effectively.

- Live Demo: ADR in Action – Witness how ADR tools identify and mitigate threats in real-world attack scenarios. This hands-on demonstration will show how vulnerabilities are detected and the incredible context that ADR can provide you to contextualize and respond efficiently

- Best Practices for Implementing ADR in Your Organization – Learn how to integrate ADR into your security stack, optimize response strategies, and minimize incident response times.

- Case Studies & Lessons from the Field – Explore real-world examples of ADR preventing attacks, from small-scale application breaches to large-scale enterprise threats.


Why Attend?

With cyber threats becoming more sophisticated, traditional security measures are no longer enough. ADR offers a proactive, application-centric approach to security, ensuring that threats are detected before they cause damage. By attending this workshop, you’ll gain the knowledge and skills needed to stay ahead of attackers, protect your applications
session.workshopAttendeeInformationsEn:
Dear workshop participant,the technical requirements for the workshop are as follows:

On-site participants:
  • Laptop with an internet connection is required
  • Should have headphones with mic to collaborate with remote participants if needed.
  • Please think of a suitable socket adapter for your notebooks
Remote participants:
  • The workshop will take place exclusively in Zoom for remote participants. Communication will take place via Zoom Chat.
  • Audio (and video) setup to be able to actively participate.


Technical Requirements:

- Laptop required.
Participants will need to bring their own laptops to actively engage in the hands-on exercises. The following should be installed in advance:

- A web browser (Chrome or Firefox recommended).

- Text editor (e.g., Visual Studio Code, Sublime Text) for code exploration.

- Access to the internet for web-based tools and exercises.

- All other necessary tools and instructions will be provided during the workshop.


We wish you a successful workshop and look forward to seeing you!

Best regards,
Conference Team
session.name: Workshop - Beyond Firewalls: DevOps-Driven Application Security with ADR & Real-Time Threat Detection
session.details:
In today’s fast-paced digital world, cyber threats lurk in the shadows, waiting to exploit vulnerabilities in your applications. This hands-on workshop is designed to help developers, security teams, and IT professionals understand how Application Detection & Response (ADR) can detect, report and block these threats before they cause damage.

Through real-world case studies, live demos, and interactive discussions, you'll learn how ADR works, why traditional security measures fall short, and how to implement proactive defense strategies to keep your applications safe. Join us and take your application security to the next level!

session.name: How Developer Platforms Fail (And How Yours Won’t)
session.details:
Platform engineering promises so much, from developer productivity to better operational efficiency, and yet the Trough of Disillusionment still beckons. "Over promised, over sold and over here", if you're in a company of more than 50 people and growing you're almost guaranteed to have creating a platform to help you scale safely and cost-effectively. But how do you doge the disillusionment and develop what delivers?

In this entertaining and thoughtful keynote, Russ Miles (Developer, Listener, Author and Builder of platforms) will unpack the myths around platform engineering. Touring a collection of real-world examples where platforms swim or sink through the lense of philosophy, Russ will explore the many choices you can make that will make the difference between a successful platform that your teams will love and a franken-platform that no one wants to touch.

Together we'll explore which myths hold and which fold under scrutiny so that you have the best possible chance of building a loved internal developer platform. Why? 

Because your developers are worth it(TM).

session.name: The Great Security Splits: Replacing Pain with Joy in the Middle
session.details:
Developers shift left. Security shifts right. And in the middle? That’s where things get painful. As teams pull in opposite directions - using vastly different tools - AppSec can feel like doing the splits. Workflows get stretched to their limit, innovation slows, and frustration builds where it hurts the most.
But what if security didn’t have to be a source of strain? What if we could flex, adapt, and create a way of working that sparks joy instead of friction? Because let’s be honest: running with a high heel on one foot and a sneaker on the other won’t get you far.
In this talk, Paul shares personal stories of struggle, growth, and the search for better ways of working - because security shouldn’t come at the cost of happiness. We’ll explore how to remove the pain points of AppSec, build more satisfying workflows, and reclaim your right to enjoy the work you do every day. The best security isn’t just strong - it’s seamless, supportive, and even fun.
Let’s find a better way together.

session.name: Fine-Grained Access Control (FGA) in Focus - Best Practices for Developers
session.details:
Many developers rely on traditional role-based access control (RBAC) in their applications. However,
in modern system architectures, RBAC often reaches its limits. Dynamic permissions, contextual
dependencies, and multi-tenant environments require a more precise and adaptable access model.
Fine-Grained Access Control (FGA) delivers exactly that — enabling highly tailored, context-aware
authorization logic that integrates seamlessly with microservices, cloud platforms, and scalable
architectures .
But how can these concepts be put into practice?
In this talk, the speaker will walk through real-world use cases to show how organizations can
enhance their security architecture using FGA. A live hacking session will illustrate the vulnerabilities
of traditional access control approaches and demonstrate common attack vectors.
Participants will then explore a best-practice implementation that highlights how FGA can be
successfully integrated into existing systems. 
This session is tailored for developers and security professionals seeking to deepen their knowledge
of modern access control strategies through practical, real-life examples.

session.name: Welcome and Opening Keynote of IT Security Summit Munich 2025
session.details: Welcome and opening remarks of IT Security Summit Munich 2025 by the Program Chair Sebastian Meyen.

session.name: Preparing for the quantum leap: What post-quantum cryptography means for devs
session.details: As quantum computing evolves from theory to reality, the cryptographic foundations of today's digital infrastructure are under threat. Post-Quantum Cryptography (PQC) aims to secure data against future quantum attacks, but the shift will not be seamless. This talk explores how the transition to PQC will affect developers—from libraries and APIs to key sizes, performance trade-offs, and integration challenges. We'll demystify NIST's PQC standardization efforts, examine real-world implications of deploying quantum-resistant algorithms, and outline what developers can do now to future-proof their applications. Whether you're working on secure communications, embedded systems, or cloud services, understanding PQC is critical. This is not just a cryptography problem—it’s a software engineering challenge.

session.name: DevOpsCon Exchange (ON-SITE ONLY)
session.details:
One of the key principles of DevOps is based on sharing knowledge and experience. There's no better place to do that than at a conference where so many DevOps professionals meet! Come along and discuss the topics that matter most to you with a group of passionate, like-minded people.

We’re setting up three special discussion tables, spotlighting the topics Kubernetes, Platform Engineering, and Business & Company Culture to spark conversation and connection after a full day of learning. Whether you want to trade tips on container orchestration, swap ideas on building better internal platforms, or discuss how people make DevOps happen, including culture and leadership, there’s a place for you. Pull up a chair, share your experiences, and enjoy some great conversations with fellow DevOps enthusiasts.

session.name: Protect Your Frontend: Why JWTs Should Stay Backstage
session.details: As frontend developers, we want to create smooth, user-friendly experiences, but security often takes a backseat to functionality. In this talk, we'll dive into JSON Web Tokens (JWTs) and why storing them in the frontend is a recipe for disaster. Through some real-world examples, we'll explore the risks associated with this practice, from token theft to session hijacking. As a solution we'll discuss the principles of backend-for-frontends (BFF) and how it can save your application from becoming a hacker's playground. By the end of this session, you'll not only be convinced to keep JWTs out of your frontend, but you'll also be armed with practical strategies to enhance your app's security without sacrificing performance.

session.name: Securing the Speed of Innovation: How AI-Driven Development and Security Drive Success
session.details:
In today’s fast-paced software environments, development speed and security can no longer exist in isolation. AI is transforming how code is written, reviewed, and deployed—turning traditional bottlenecks into opportunities for innovation. Yet this acceleration also introduces new challenges around reliability, compliance, and exposure to risk. 

This session explores how AI-driven development and security teams can effectively collaborate to secure innovation without slowing delivery. Drawing from real-world DevSecOps practices, we’ll discuss how AI can help detect vulnerabilities earlier, reduce incident response times, and improve the overall resilience of software pipelines. 

Key questions include: 

• How does AI change the role of code review?
• What liabilities arise from AI-generated code?
• And how can organizations ensure AI remains a sustainable enabler rather than a new source of risk?

session.name: Securing the SDLC: From Container Images to AI Agents
session.details: This presentation examines the evolution of supply chain security challenges from container images to AI agents. We'll explore how modern development practices create new attack vectors, from containers running hundreds of unnecessary packages to AI agents accessing enterprise systems without proper security controls. The session demonstrates solutions like hardened images that dramatically reduce attack surfaces and examines emerging Model Context Protocol vulnerabilities. Through analysis of real incidents and threat patterns, we'll show how to apply container best practice, to build secure AI-enhanced development environments before attacks spread.

session.name: Walking the path: addressing real-world threats with Application Detection and Response (ADR)
session.details:
An effective application security program focuses on applying the right tools and processes at the right moment. But you will need to rethink your security strategy beyond shift-left practices; while identifying and fixing vulnerabilities early in development before deploying to production is essential, it is simply not enough.
The reality is that vulnerabilities inevitably make it into production. Many security programs overlook how to deal with attacks against the vulnerabilities that were missed. Application Detection and Response (ADR) fills this critical gap by providing real-time visibility into running applications and the ability to block attacks on application vulnerabilities in your production applications.

session.name: The AI Code War: When Generative AI Meets Generative Malware
session.details:
We are in an AI Code War. While generative AI accelerates development, attackers match this speed with their own models to automate exploits. This velocity creates two critical challenges: AI writing inherently vulnerable code and “secure” code decaying faster than any human patching cycle can manage. This rapid decay creates invisible attack paths that traditional security pipelines cannot detect.
 In this talk, we will demonstrate how AI can write vulnerable code in seconds, how attackers use AI to identify and exploit those weaknesses just as fast, and introduce Vibe Security — an emerging discipline focused on defending code as it evolves, not just scanning artifacts once they are produced. Attendees will learn how to detect, visualize, and secure the unpredictable code that AI now writes at scale. If development accelerates, security must accelerate too — otherwise, the attacker wins by default.

session.name: Rise of the Machines
session.details:
Modern attackers now operate at machine speed, powered by AI systems that independently scan, adapt, and execute complex attack chains across cloud environments. These autonomous agents can exploit CI/CD pipelines, pivot through workloads, and weaponize misconfigurations in seconds. The result is a threat landscape where cloud and CI/CD environments can be breached in seconds. 

In this session, Marcel breaks down how agentic AI is transforming both sides of the cybersecurity battlefield. He reveals why runtime protection has become essential — and how defenders can finally fight back by deploying their own agentic AI systems. These defensive agents can continuously monitor runtime activity, correlate signals, respond autonomously, and out-pace human-driven SOC workflows. Instead of reacting to threats, agentic AI helps organizations predict, prevent, and contain attacks before they escalate. 

The next wave of threats is evolving autonomously. Your defenses need to keep pace.

session.name: Scaling Cybersecurity Training Through Automated Exercise Generation
session.details:
Cybersecurity exercises are essential for preparing organizations to handle modern cyber threats, yet their creation remains slow, complex, and prohibitively expensive. This talk presents recent research and applied development by CyberArrange Security Solutions on automating the generation of cyber-range environments and training scenarios using large language models. Building on advances in reasoning-capable LLMs, we demonstrate how end-to-end automation, from environment provisioning to vulnerability implementation and scenario testing, can drastically reduce the time, expertise, and cost required to produce high-quality cyber exercises.

We showcase results from our LLM development and evaluation pipeline, discuss practical performance considerations, and present a fully generated demo scenario illustrating automated reconnaissance, exploitation, privilege escalation, and social-engineering steps. The talk also highlights broader research directions: security for SMEs, critical-infrastructure protection, and the role of digital sovereignty in shaping Europe’s cybersecurity capability.
